title: Relates to the granting of higher education degrees by authorized institutions; repealer
summary: Relates to the granting of higher education degrees by authorized institutions; provides that no entity shall confer a degree upon an individual unless it is an authorized institution or all of its programs are authorized programs.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1721

TITLE OF BILL:

An act
to amend the education law, in relation to the university of the state
of New York; and to repeal section 224 of such law relating thereto

PURPOSE:

To protect citizens of this state from people holding inadequate or
fraudulently obtained college degrees as well as protecting potential
students from substandard institutions.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

Section 1. Defines this act as "The Integrity of Higher Education
Degrees, and Education Consumer Protection Act of 2011."

Section 2. Repeals section 224 of the education law.

Section 3. Creates a new section 224 of the education law establishing
criteria for the authorization of colleges and universities to confer
and advertise degrees as well as prohibiting fraud in the claiming of
a college or university degree.

Section 4. Requires the state education department to create a list,
available on the internet, of colleges and universities that are
authorized to confer or advertise a degree, as well as a list of
those institutions that are known to the department and not
authorized to advertise or confer a degree in this state, and whose
degrees are not valid in this state.

JUSTIFICATION:

Not every college offering a degree is accredited by an accrediting
agency that is recognized by the United States Department of
Education. This accreditation represents a kind of minimum standard
of quality and integrity. Some colleges that are not accredited will
issue college degrees without requiring any work on the part of the
student. Credits and degrees earned at these unaccredited schools
generally are not accepted by other schools or professional licensing
boards.

The rise of diploma mills taking advantage of New York State residents
has become an increasing problem. Hundreds of unaccredited colleges
operate in the United States today, with a wide range of quality.
Some are legitimate, but many are fraudulent. It has been estimated
that these fraudulent institutions earn over two million dollars each
year. This legislation is necessary in order to protect citizens of
this state from people holding inadequate or fraudulently obtained

college degrees as well as protecting potential students from
substandard institutions.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:

2009-10 S.1768; S.3902, 2007-08; S.3300, 2005-2006.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

Immediately.
